author: Kakugen

text: Yeah, I miss the good old days back in 2009 and 2010 when the game came out. It was the fucking shit and still is. I just miss the multiplayer so much, wish the collection came with remastered multiplayer. But besides that I believe Uncharted 2 is one of, if not the best game ever plot wise and in many other aspects like the chemistry between characters and how real you can relate to them. The pacing of Uncharted 2 is phenomenal I also think Uncharted 4 did a good job at that. Like you will have a chill cut scene one moment and then you're guns blazing in the next. I think Uncharted 2 has the strongest soundtrack. It fits the game so well with the plotline of Marco Polo and Shambhala which I also think are interesting. Naughty Dog knows how to make games and I can count on them with whatever they make next. I heard they're doing Last of Us 2 after U4 DLC, and also working on a new IP maybe.
author: RenegadeX025

text: @RenegadeX025 There were just something missing from UC4 that Uncharted 2 had. I know that TLOU was a big influence on UC4.
author: Kakugen

text: It's because Uncharted 2 is more ground-breaking than Uncharted 4. Look at Drake's Fortune then compare it to Among Thieves. It's like comparing the original Assassin's Creed to Assassin's Creed II. It's feels fresh and new and original and a far better sequel than it's predecessor. The level of improvements and how in-depth they went to fix shit from the first installment to flush out the gameplay was epic. not to mention the amazing plot. It's like watching an action-adventure movie but playing it. Uncharted 2 is one of the nearest games to perfection (since it's so close, it is perfect). Nothing better can fit the level of correlation between the gameplay, characters, plot, and the soundtrack. They took all those elements and punched you in the face with it because it mixed so well together to create an epic game. Uncharted 4 is in my opinion pretty satisfying, but i Know where you come from when you say you don't feel the same way about 2.
author: RenegadeX025

text:
@RenegadeX025
exactly what i was going to write.. , one of the things that makes U2 so memorable is how they got EVERYTHING from the first game (which was good but not great) and did it 100000x times better and epic, plot, characters, graphics, music, levels, gameplay, you name it, it was , as you said, groundbreaking for the genre and the series ,¬† the rest of the Uncharted were but more of the (still DAMN good.) and trying to put NAthan on different situations to mantain the game fresh. (desert, airplane fight, ship graveyard /escaping from sinking ship, mud skiing lol¬† etc etc) AC1 and 2 is a very good comparison!
author: edseiya

text: @edseiya well, U4 improved on the series as much as U2 did. I mean, Uncharted 4 is the only one that allows you to do proper exploration, which is crazy since the game is supposed to put you in the shoes of an explorer. the rope also allows for much better gameplay scenarios that make regular enemy encounters seem more like setpieces. U4 is also the one that explores more the character of Nathan Drake, showing moments from before U1 and moments in the future too, it feels like a much more well rounded and complete experience. with that being said, I still missed a bit a completely crazy iconic setpiece (that hadn't been shown prior to release). I probably would've been fine with it if the game had another mindblowing moment like that, but that was it, that was the big moment and showed it all at E3, that's the biggest problem with U4 (and probably only one worth mentioning)

author: Scarlet DarkAngel

text: If you listen to each soundtrack closely they chose a certain instrument for each game. The one featured in Marco Polo being the one for the 2nd. The one featured I believe in Drake's Elegy, which is a beautiful song, in the 1st soundtrack, it sounds like a bass flute (yes that is spelled right, look it up), the flute seems to be primary in most of the songs in the first one. The third one goes for, seems to me, a more Middle East feel to it, hence the vocals and thus the instrument featured tailors to the Middle East. I believe it is most featured in Mind Games, as well as others. Now I could be wrong. I apologize if I offend anyone. No one is right all the time, it's just a little food for thought, and interesting to think about if you appreciate this kind of music like I do. Enjoy UC2! And get psyched for UC4!! :D Cheers! <3
